nodes.text: Intergenerational income mobility in the United States varies substantially across geographic areas and is systematically associated with observable local characteristics

Method: Constructed population-level links between children (born 1980–1982) and parents using deidentified federal tax records (1996–2012); measured parent family income as mean 1996–2000 and child family income as mean 2011–2012 (age ~30)

Measurement: Prefer rank-rank specification (children and parents ranked nationally) to summarize mobility; define relative mobility by rank-rank slope and absolute mobility by predicted child rank at parent percentile p (focus on p=25)
National result: The national rank-rank slope is 0.341 (a 10 percentile increase in parent rank predicts a 3.41 percentile increase in child rank); relationship is nearly linear in ranks

Claim about IGE: Canonical log-log IGE estimates are unstable (sensitive to nonlinearities and treatment of zero incomes) yielding IGEs from ~0.26 to 0.70 across specifications, motivating use of rank-rank

Spatial result: Large CZ-level variation in both relative and absolute mobility; examples: probability of moving from bottom quintile to top quintile is 4.4% in Charlotte vs 12.9% in San Jose; absolute upward mobility (predicted rank at p=25) ranges from about 35.8 to 46.2 among large CZs

Claim: Five broad area-level factors are strongly correlated with upward mobility: (i) residential segregation, (ii) income inequality (especially among bottom 99%), (iii) school quality (test scores, dropout rates, income-adjusted), (iv) social capital, and (v) family structure (single-parent share)

Robustness and identification caveat: Estimates robust to life-cycle bias (child income stabilizes by age ~30), attenuation (5-year parent average adequate), alternative income definitions, cost-of-living and growth adjustments; correlations are not causal and may reflect endogenous selection

Intermediate outcomes result: Parent rank is strongly linearly related to college attendance (slope ~0.675; 10 percentile parent increase => 6.7 percentage point increase in college attendance) and to teenage birth rates (10 percentile increase => 3 percentage point reduction), and these gradients vary spatially similar to income mobility
Evidence (national transition matrix): Quintile transition matrix shows 7.5% chance nationally of rising from bottom to top quintile; lower than Denmark (11.7%) and Canada (13.4%)

Conclusion: The United States is a set of local labor-markets/societies with heterogeneous opportunity; publicly released CZ/county mobility statistics can guide research and policy on local determinants, but causal inference requires further identification
Evidence supporting national rank-rank slope: Binned and microdata OLS regressions on ~10 million core-sample children yield rank-rank slope 0.341 (SE 0.0003), robustness across subsamples

Evidence for CZ examples and magnitude: CZ regressions (one per CZ) summarize conditional child rank by intercept and slope; example estimates: r25=46.2 Salt Lake City, r25=35.8 Charlotte; population-weighted SD of r25 ~3.34, unweighted SD ~5.68

Evidence for correlates: Univariate correlations with r25: racial segregation (Theil index) corr ≈ -0.36; income segregation and bottom-99 Gini strongly negative (bottom-99 Gini corr ≈ -0.63); school outputs (income-adjusted test scores, dropout residuals) corr ≈ 0.6; social capital index corr ≈ 0.64; fraction single-parent children corr ≈ -0.76; multivariate regressions keep many factors significant controlling for state fixed effects though causality not established
